newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine oil firms blame river leaks on weather.
newsitem.headline: Argentine oil firms blame river leaks on weather.

text.p: Argentine oil companies said Thursday recent damage to pipelines which caused leaks of crude oil into the Colorado river were caused by bad weather.

"The leaks were caused by torrential rain and slides of water and rocks which are completely abnormal in the area," the companies YPF, Perez Companc, Petrolera San Jorge, Mexpetrol and Oldeval said in a paid advertisement published in local newspapers.
The Rio Colorado crosses some 1,500 kilometers (900 miles) through central Argentina from the Andes to the Atlantic.
As many as 300,000 liters of crude oil may have seeped into the river upstream, where the oil wells are located, after recent storms, according to media reports.

The companies claimed that before the latest leakages February 16 and March 6 they had hired international consultants to carry out an impact study but nobody had warned of the risk of the present damage.

"There are no possible precautions you can take when 100 milimeters of rain fall in 20 minutes and a torrent of water digs up earth 3.5 meters (11.6 feet) deep, exposing pipes which are hit by rocks weighing up to two tonnes," the companies said.
They said they were currently cleaning up affected areas.
Local authorities in western Neuquen province told Reuters this week the river had already cleansed itself to a large extent thanks to its strong current.
But at least one province, Rio Negro, was considering suing the oil companies for damage to riverside crops through lack of clean water.
The governors of the five provinces the river runs through are scheduled to meet Monday to discuss the oil spills which they say have become a chronic problem in recent years.
